results.title: Occupy Wall Street protestors in New York City
results.brief_description: In 2011, the connectivity and speed of social media seemed promising for society and democracy. Platforms like Facebook, Twitter and YouTube were integral to mobilising people and coordinating protest movements like Occupy Wall Street, which aims to create greater economic equality.

constellations_primary.name: Fight for your right
constellations_primary.description: Real world revolution and the fictional representations that reflect the struggle for equality in the past, present and dystopian future.

results.title: Occupy Wall St
results.brief_description: Occupy Wall Street (OWS) was a protest movement that began on September 17, 2011, in Zuccotti Park, located in New York City’s Wall Street financial district, against economic inequality. The movement spread around the world, assisted by social media and extensive media coverage, demonstrating the power of the moving image to incite protests and action.
results.description: Occupy Wall Street (OWS) was a protest movement that began on September 17, 2011, in Zuccotti Park, located in New York City’s Wall Street financial district, against economic inequality. The movement spread around the world, assisted by social media and extensive media coverage, demonstrating the power of the moving image to incite protests and action.

The movement spread around the world, assisted by social media and extensive media coverage, demonstrating the power of the moving image to incite protests and action.

results.title: Occupied territory
results.creator_credit: Candace Reckinger and University of California, Los Angeles
results.brief_description: In a society plagued with decay and political chaos, a woman is arrested for the murder of her lover. This film is a portrayal of a female terrorist group and their actions of protest against our society’s exploitation of women’s bodies. The concepts that are communicated by the film are presented in an experimental form.

results.title: Occupational therapy
results.creator_credit: Mutual Film Corporation and Career Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Is this your career series”.
A vocational guidance film showing how occupational therapists assist disabled people, by devising jobs and exercises, to recover their sense of independence. Demonstrates techniques and shows training briefly.

results.title: Occupational health & safety act of Victoria
results.brief_description: A program to explain how the Safety Act relates to the workplace of Victoria. Part 1. Introduction and outline of respective duties of employers manufactures and employees and roles of the Department of Labour. Victorian Occupational Health and Safety Commission and occupational health and safety representatives. Part 2. Looks at keys to success with consultative arrangements for resolving workplace issues. Part 3. Outlines ways problems can be resolved.

Part 3. Outlines ways problems can be resolved.

results.title: Occupational First Aid
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Support”.
Occupational First Aid is the emergency treatment for accidents or illnesses which occur in the workplace. This program looks at the skills required to be a First Aider and at the content and location of First Aid kits in the workplace. First Aiders must be multi-skilled persons able to provide emergency treatment, make decisions regarding treatment or refer, dress and re-dress minor injuries, maintain and stock First Aid kits, actively participate in Safety programs and be familiar with the workplace.

results.title: Obstruction
results.brief_description:
Compiling short video sequences from documentary filmmakers, journalists and video activists including Peter Vaughan, John Flynn, Pip Starr, Russell Hawkins, Kim Beamish, John Hughes, Izzy, SKA TV and Paul O’Connor
(Undercurrents), Riley highlights the potential hazards of their work. Obstruction details the physical frustration involved in gathering evidence: the intervention of law enforcement and figures of authority or the recurring use of the hand to cover the camera’s lens, thereby obscuring our vision.

The staccato bursts of movement and blurred point-of-view in Obstruction challenge the notion of a centralised, transcendent eye/I behind the camera. Riley’s camera is a witness to the ways in which evidence is mediated and subject to the whim of external forces outside the filmmaker’s control. All the media artists featured in Obstruction have experienced physical disruptions in their search for proof. Prevented from continuing to record particular events and activities, Riley questions whether the public’s right-to-know is overruled by the right to privacy on behalf of the individual or corporation.
